awd_titl_txt: Strategies for Leading Classroom Discussions Aimed at Core Ideas and Scientific Modeling Practices
awd_abstract_narration:
The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) have set goals for students to learn scientific models as disciplinary core ideas in addition to scientific reasoning practices and cross cutting ideas.  Given these advances in national standards, educators are now asking for details about: (a) strategies for teaching the core disciplinary ideas; (b) how to teach the components of scientific thinking practices; and (c) how to integrate those practices with the teaching of core ideas. This project will use video case studies to identify key strategies used by exemplary teachers to guide class discussions toward these goals. The project will study teachers in the areas of high school mechanics and electricity, and middle school life sciences, and is designed to develop the constructs and language that will enable us to describe key discussion leading strategies. Clarified descriptions of the strategies will be disseminated to teachers via a website on discussion leading strategies for building models as core ideas, and accompanied by real classroom examples.  

In order to organize the strategies, the project will also combine the results of the classroom case studies with findings from studies of thinking processes in scientists to develop an integrated theoretical framework for model based learning and teaching in science.  The theoretical framework will serve as a guide for organizing instruction, integrating research findings, and sequencing strategies for teacher educators and curriculum developers.  The framework will start from practices in the NGSS standards for modeling and add detail by identifying smaller practices and supporting teaching strategies at four different time scale levels--from 5-second engagements with mental simulations, to the use of minutes-long constructive reasoning processes, to larger modeling cycles lasting roughly 10 minutes to hours, to model construction modes that can last 15 minutes to days.  A simplified version of the theoretical framework will give a way to introduce teachers to strategies in an organized manner, one level at a time. The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools (RMTs). Projects in the DRK-12 program build on fundamental research in STEM education and prior research and development efforts that provide theoretical and empirical justification for proposed projects.

por.por_cntn:
Science Discussions Emphasizing Modeling

The Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS) identifies Developing and Using Models as one of the eight science and engineering practices that all students should engage in, and as a context within which Disciplinary Core Ideas should be taught. Although the national standards provide some initial guidelines, educators are now asking for more details about how to teach the components of Modeling as a scientific practice, while teaching Disciplinary Core Ideas at the same time. This project used video case studies to identify key strategies used by experienced teachers to guide classroom discussions toward a deep conceptual understanding of science topics in the context of students engaging in the practice of developing and revising scientific models. A key gap in our educational system is that teachers have insufficient training in how to lead productive discussions. The project studied classroom discussions in the areas of high school mechanics and electricity and middle school life sciences, and was designed to develop the constructs and language that will enable us to describe key discussion-leading strategies.

For example, one middle school teacher had students try to create and draw models of how one's throat is structured so that we can easily eat or breathe. The teacher fostered this discussion by: using strategies like first having students generate, draw, and share their models; then asking for evidence based problems they saw in the models; then asking about ways to fix the problems. During each of these phases she also used imagery support strategies such as recording all ideas in drawings, asking students to imagine how their model would function (or not), and both using and asking for gestures. Students were successful in revising their models in several improvement cycles until the teacher confirmed that they were much like the anatomical model. Other important strategies, like analogies, or having students participate in designing an experiment or thought experiment or extreme case have also been documented. Experienced teachers use many important strategies intuitively that they cannot describe very well to others, such as having students generate, evaluate, and modify models. The video case studies have generated clarifying vocabulary terms for describing several dozen major cognitive strategies.

Framework for Organizing Discussion Leading Strategies

With input from studies of thinking processes in real scientists, the project has also developed a framework for organizing the strategies so that others can comprehend and remember them efficiently. The framework starts from practices in the NGSS standards for modeling and adds detail by identifying smaller practices and supporting teaching strategies at four different time scale levels--from 5-second engagements with mental simulations, to the use of minutes-long constructive reasoning processes, to larger modeling cycles lasting roughly 10 minutes to hours, to model construction modes that can last 15 minutes to days. In simplified form, the framework should give us a way to introduce teachers to new strategies in an organized way, one level at a time. The framework can serve as a guide for integrating research findings, organizing instruction, and sequencing strategies for teacher educators and curriculum developers.

Outcomes

The project has also studied student outcomes from model based teaching. For example, one study analyzed the strategies of exemplary physics teachers who are using an innovative curriculum to teach units on electricity in classrooms where large confidence gains, as well as conceptual gains, were measured that were significantly higher than a control group's gains, for female as well as male students.

Website on Strategies for Leading Modeling Discussions

 The project has sought to broaden its impact through published reports for teachers as well as researchers and by creating a website designed primarily for teacher educators to use with teachers.  The website describes all of the model-based teaching strategies identified by the project, organized according to the framework described above, and accompanied by illustrative classroom examples. Explicit strategies for discussion-leading are not emphasized enough in teacher education courses. The project estimates that the best chance interested teachers have of exposure to discussion-leading strategies that support inquiry and scientific modeling will be in graduate level education courses. Materials for such courses are sorely needed. The website is designed, with teacher educators in mind, to support use of the material in a course and by the teachers themselves as they begin to put these ideas into practice. The classroom examples provided on the site are from case studies of teachers who have been consistently successful at getting students to talk to each other, to reason aloud, to put forth ideas with the understanding that they may revise them later, and to converge on targeted core ideas. Thus, these students have not only learned complex scientific models, but have been strongly engaged in modeling as a scientific practice.
